sen.j: 親藩（しんぱん）は、江戸時代の藩の分類の一つで、徳川家康の男系男子・子孫が始祖となっている藩を指す。
sen.e: Shinpan is one of the classifications of clans in Edo period, and indicates clans, forefathers of which were male descendants through a line of males of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
Shinpan is one of the classifications of clans during the Edo period, that distinguished the clans forefathers as male descendants through a line of males from Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
Shinpan is one of the classifications of clans during the Edo period, that distinguished the clans forefathers as male descendants through a line of males from Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 特に、「徳川氏」を称する徳川御三家、御三卿の当主は家康の男系男子・子孫に限られ、徳川将軍家の血筋が絶えたときには、後継ぎを出す役割を担った。
sen.e: Especially the heads of Tokugawa "gosanke" and "gosankyo" (three privileged branches of the Tokugawa family, respectively) who referred to themselves as 'TOKUGAWA' were limited to male descendants through a line of males of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and if the line of the Tokugawa Shogunate family failed, they played a role to provide an heir.

Especially the heads of Tokugawa "gosanke" and "gosankyo" (three privileged branches of the Tokugawa family, respectively) who referred to themselves as 'TOKUGAWA' were limited to male descendants through a line of males from Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and if the line of the Tokugawa Shogunate family failed, they played a role to provide an heir.

Especially the heads of Tokugawa "gosanke" and "gosankyo" (three privileged branches of the Tokugawa family, respectively) who referred to themselves as 'TOKUGAWA' were limited to male descendants through a line of males from Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and if the line of the Tokugawa Shogunate family failed, they played a role to provide an heir.

sen.j: その他の家は「松平氏」を名乗った。
sen.e: Other families referred to themselves as 'MATSUDAIRA'.
Other families referred to themselves as 'MATSUDAIRA'.
Other families referred to themselves as 'MATSUDAIRA'.

sen.j: 上記以外に、徳川家光、徳川綱吉の正室の実家の出身とされる鷹司松平家も親藩とされる。
sen.e: Apart from the above, the Takatsukasa-Matsudaira family, which was from the family home of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA and Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA's lawful wives, was to be shinpan as well.
Apart from the above, the Takatsukasa-Matsudaira family, from the family home of Iemitsu and Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA's lawful wives, was shinpan as well.
Apart from the above, the Takatsukasa-Matsudaira family, from the family home of Iemitsu and Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA's lawful wives, was shinpan as well.

sen.j: （徳川忠長の遺子松平長七郎の子孫というのは俗説）
sen.e: (It is a superstition that it was a descendant of Tadanaga TOKUGAWA's bereaved child, Choshichiro MATSUDAIRA.)
(It is a superstition to believe that it was a descendant of Tadanaga TOKUGAWA's bereaved child, Choshichiro MATSUDAIRA.)
(It is a superstition to believe that it was a descendant of Tadanaga TOKUGAWA's bereaved child, Choshichiro MATSUDAIRA.)

sen.j: また、家康の女系男子・子孫奥平松平家や家康の異父弟・子孫である久松松平家も親藩に準じて取り扱われることもある。
sen.e: And sometimes the Okudaira-Matsudaira family, a male descendant through a line of females of Ieyasu and the Hisamatsu-Matsudaira family, a descendant of Ieyasu's younger maternal half-brother, were also treated as well as shinpan.

And sometimes the Okudaira-Matsudaira family, a male descendant through a line of females of Ieyasu and the Hisamatsu-Matsudaira family, a descendant of Ieyasu's younger maternal half-brother, were also treated as shinpan.

And sometimes the Okudaira-Matsudaira family, a male descendant through a line of females of Ieyasu and the Hisamatsu-Matsudaira family, a descendant of Ieyasu's younger maternal half-brother, were also treated as shinpan.

sen.j: なお、狭義の親藩には御三家・御三卿は含まれない。
sen.e: However, narrowly defined shinpan doesn't include gosanke and gosankyo.
However, narrowly defined, shinpan doesn't include gosanke and gosankyo.
However, narrowly defined, shinpan doesn't include gosanke and gosankyo.

sen.j: 以下の徳川御三家は、徳川家康の男系男子・子孫であり、親藩の中でもさらに別格の扱いだった。
sen.e: The following Tokugawa gosanke are the male descendants through a line of males of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and were given even more special treatment within shinpan.
The following Tokugawa gosanke are the male descendants through the line of males of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and were given even extra special treatment within shinpan.
The following Tokugawa gosanke are the male descendants through the line of males of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and were given even extra special treatment within shinpan.

sen.j: 徳川義直を初代藩主とする尾張藩
sen.e: The Owari clan, the first lord of which was Yoshinao TOKUGAWA
The Owari clan, the first lord Yoshinao TOKUGAWA
The Owari clan, the first lord Yoshinao TOKUGAWA

sen.j: 徳川頼宣を初代藩主とする紀州藩
sen.e: the Kishu clan, the first lord of which was Yorinobu TOKUGAWA
the Kishu clan, the first lord Yorinobu TOKUGAWA
the Kishu clan, the first lord Yorinobu TOKUGAWA

sen.j: 徳川頼房を初代藩主とする水戸藩
sen.e: the Mito clan, the first lord of which was Yorifusa TOKUGAWA
the Mito clan, the first lord Yorifusa TOKUGAWA
the Mito clan, the first lord Yorifusa TOKUGAWA

sen.j: これらの三家はもし将軍家（徳川宗家）に男系男子（将軍継嗣）が無ければ、将軍を出すように決められていた。
sen.e: These three clans had to provide shogun if the Shogun family (the head of the Tokugawa family) lacked a male through a line of males (an heir of Shogun).
These three clans had to provide a shogun if the Shogun family (the head of the Tokugawa family) lacked a male through a line of males (an heir to Shogun).
These three clans had to provide a shogun if the Shogun family (the head of the Tokugawa family) lacked a male through a line of males (an heir to Shogun).

sen.j: また、徳川姓を名乗ること（他の一門は松平姓）や、三つ葉葵の家紋の使用などが許されていた。
sen.e: And they were allowed to call themselves Tokugawa (other "ichimon", family-related clans of the Tokugawa family, called themselves Matsudaira), and also to use "Mitsuba-aoi no kamon" (family crest of three leaves of Hollyhock).

And they were allowed to call themselves Tokugawa (other "ichimon", family-related clans of the Tokugawa family, called themselves Matsudaira), and also use "Mitsuba-aoi no kamon" (family crest of three leaves of Hollyhock).

And they were allowed to call themselves Tokugawa (other "ichimon", family-related clans of the Tokugawa family, called themselves Matsudaira), and also use "Mitsuba-aoi no kamon" (family crest of three leaves of Hollyhock).

sen.j: ただし、当初は将軍家・尾張家・紀州家をもって御三家（水戸は入っておらず）と称した。
sen.e: But at first, the Shogun family, the Owari family, and the Kishu family were referred to as gosanke (the Mito family was not included).
But at first, the Shogun family, the Owari family, and the Kishu family were referred to as gosanke (the Mito family was not included).
But at first, the Shogun family, the Owari family, and the Kishu family were referred to as gosanke (the Mito family was not included).

sen.j: 八代将軍徳川吉宗は紀州藩主から、十四代将軍徳川家茂は紀州藩主から、十五代将軍徳川慶喜は水戸徳川家から一橋家当主を経て将軍となっている。
sen.e: Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, the eighth shogun became shogun through the lord of the Kishu clan, and so did Iemochi TOKUGAWA, the fourteenth Shogun, through the lord of the Kishu clan, and also did Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the fifteenth Shogun, from the Mito-Tokugawa family through the head of the Hitotsubashi family.

Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, the eighth shogun became shogun through the lord of the Kishu clan, and so did Iemochi TOKUGAWA, the fourteenth Shogun, through the lord of the Kishu clan, as also did Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the fifteenth Shogun, from the Mito-Tokugawa family through the head of the Hitotsubashi family.

Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, the eighth shogun became shogun through the lord of the Kishu clan, and so did Iemochi TOKUGAWA, the fourteenth Shogun, through the lord of the Kishu clan, as also did Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the fifteenth Shogun, from the Mito-Tokugawa family through the head of the Hitotsubashi family.

sen.j: 吉宗の時代にさらに下記のようにいわゆる御三卿が設けられた。
sen.e: In addition, during the Yoshimune era, following so-called gosankyo was established.
In addition, during the Yoshimune era, the so-called gosankyo was established.
In addition, during the Yoshimune era, the so-called gosankyo was established.

sen.j: 徳川宗武を初代当主とする田安家
sen.e: the Tayasu family which was first headed by Munetake TOKUGAWA
the Tayasu family first headed by Munetake TOKUGAWA
the Tayasu family first headed by Munetake TOKUGAWA

sen.j: 徳川宗尹を初代当主とする一橋家
sen.e: the Hitotsubashi family which was first headed by Munetada TOKUGAWA
the Hitotsubashi family first headed by Munetada TOKUGAWA
the Hitotsubashi family first headed by Munetada TOKUGAWA

sen.j: それに九代将軍徳川家重の代に
sen.e: and during the Ieshige TOKUGAWA, the ninth shogun era
and during the Ieshige TOKUGAWA, the ninth shogun era
and during the Ieshige TOKUGAWA, the ninth shogun era

sen.j: 徳川重好を初代当主とする清水家
sen.e: the Shimizu family which was first headed by Shigeyoshi TOKUGAWA
the Shimizu family first headed by Shigeyoshi TOKUGAWA
the Shimizu family first headed by Shigeyoshi TOKUGAWA

sen.j: 御三卿は「将軍の家族」として扱われた。
sen.e: Gosankyo was treated as the "Shogun families ".
Gosankyo were treated as "Shogun families. "
Gosankyo were treated as "Shogun families. "

sen.j: 御三家・御三卿に次ぐ一門としては徳川家康の二男・（徳川秀忠の兄）結城秀康を祖とする越前松平家、徳川秀忠の子（徳川家光の異母弟）保科正之を祖とする会津松平家などがあった。
sen.e: There were also families (ichimo) next to gosanke and gosankyo, such as the Echizen Matsudaira family, a forefather of which was Hideyasu YUKI, the second son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA (Hidetada's older brothor), and the Aizu-Matsudaira family, a forefather of which was Masayuki HOSHINA, the second son of Hidetada TOKUGAWA (Iemitsu TOKUGAWA's younger paternal half-brother).

There were also families (ichimo) next to gosanke and gosankyo, such as the Echizen Matsudaira family, the forefather Hideyasu YUKI, the second son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA (Hidetada's older brothor), and the Aizu-Matsudaira family, the forefather Masayuki HOSHINA, the second son of Hidetada TOKUGAWA (Iemitsu TOKUGAWA's younger paternal half-brother).

There were also families (ichimon) next to gosanke and gosankyo, such as the Echizen Matsudaira family, the forefather Hideyasu YUKI, the second son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA (Hidetada's older brothor), and the Aizu-Matsudaira family, the forefather Masayuki HOSHINA, the son of Hidetada TOKUGAWA (Iemitsu TOKUGAWA's younger paternal half-brother).
sen.cmt: ichimo → ichimonthe second son of Hidetada → the son of Hidetada

sen.j: これら一門大名は家格・官位などでは優遇されたが（将軍の親戚と言うだけであって譜代大名ではないので）幕政に参加する事は許されなかった。
sen.e: Those ichimon daimyo (family-related feudal lords) were favored in Kakaku (family status) and official ranks, but never allowed to participate in the shogunate government, as they were only shogun's relatives but not fudai daimyo (feudal lords in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family).

Those ichimon daimyo (family-related feudal lords) were favored in the Kakaku (family status) and official ranks, but never allowed to participate in the shogunate government, as they were only the shogun's relatives, but not fudai daimyo (feudal lords in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family).

Those ichimon daimyo (family-related feudal lords) were favored in the Kakaku (family status) and official ranks, but never allowed to participate in the shogunate government, as they were only the shogun's relatives, but not fudai daimyo (feudal lords in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family).

sen.j: そのため、徳川家綱の補佐役として幕政に参与した保科正之は、幕府の役職にはついていない。
sen.e: Therefore, Masayuki HOSHINA held no post in the shogunate government who took part in the government as an assistant to Ietsuna TOKUGAWA.
Therefore, Masayuki HOSHINA held no post in the shogunate government although he took part in the government as an assistant to Ietsuna TOKUGAWA.
Therefore, Masayuki HOSHINA held no post in the shogunate government although he took part in the government as an assistant to Ietsuna TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 幕末に至って安政の改革で徳川斉昭（水戸徳川家）が海防参与となり、幕政参加を許された。
sen.e: In Ansei Reform in the end of Edo Period, Nariaki TOKUGAWA (the Mito-Tokugawa family) became a coastal defense officer and was allowed to participate in the shogunate government.
In the Ansei Reform during the end of the Edo Period, Nariaki TOKUGAWA (the Mito-Tokugawa family) became a coastal defense officer and was allowed to participate in the shogunate government.
In the Ansei Reform during the end of the Edo Period, Nariaki TOKUGAWA (the Mito-Tokugawa family) became a coastal defense officer and was allowed to participate in the shogunate government.

sen.j: これは、アヘン戦争敗北を受けた清の香港割譲・開国など幕府の「危急存亡の秋」という特殊事情が反映されたものである（→安政の改革参照）。
sen.e: This was a reflection of the government's special circumstances, a 'critical moment', such as the cession of Hong Kong by Qing after the defeat of the First Opium War, and the opening of the country to the world (refer to Ansei Reform).

This was a reflection of the government's special circumstances, a 'critical moment,' such as the cession of Hong Kong by Qing after the defeat of the First Opium War, and the opening of the country to the world (refer to Ansei Reform).

This was a reflection of the government's special circumstances, a 'critical moment,' such as the cession of Hong Kong by Qing after the defeat of the First Opium War, and the opening of the country to the world (refer to Ansei Reform).

sen.j: また文久の改革では島津久光および朝廷の公武合体派公卿らの主導で出された勅命を受け松平慶永（越前松平家）、徳川慶喜（一橋徳川家）が、将軍の命令（台命・たいめい）を受け松平容保（会津松平家）が幕政に参加している。
sen.e: And in Bunkyu Reform, Yoshinaga MATSUDAIRA (the Echizen Matsudaira family) and Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA (the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family) participated in the shogunate government by an Imperial order released under the leadership of Hisamitsu SHIMAZU and the court nobles in the Imperial Court who supported the idea of uniting the court and the shogunate, and so did Katamori MATSUDAIRA (the Aizu-Matsudaira family) by an order from Shogun (taimei).

And during the Bunkyu Reform, Yoshinaga MATSUDAIRA (the Echizen Matsudaira family) and Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA (the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family) participated in the shogunate government by an Imperial order released under the leadership of Hisamitsu SHIMAZU and the court nobles in the Imperial Court who supported the idea of uniting the court and the shogunate, as did Katamori MATSUDAIRA (the Aizu-Matsudaira family) by an order from Shogun (taimei).

And during the Bunkyu Reform, Yoshinaga MATSUDAIRA (the Echizen Matsudaira family) and Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA (the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family) participated in the shogunate government by an Imperial order released under the leadership of Hisamitsu SHIMAZU and the court nobles in the Imperial Court who supported the idea of uniting the court and the shogunate, as did Katamori MATSUDAIRA (the Aizu-Matsudaira family) by an order from Shogun (taimei).
